indeed, but to be fair, jaeger kaiju and godzilla they're still impossible 
in terms of body structure they would all collapse from the gravity, plus 
the movie is over 2 freaking hours and we only got 3 fight scenes, there 
where more fight scenes in batman for crying out loud ugh as much as i love

into nothing more then a cheezy live action anime movie, oh well at least

comments.text:
+michael wime Definitely man, we're on the same page. I did like the scene, 
kind of. But for instance the new Godzilla, it's less obvious, more subtle 
in the battles. I prefer that personally, I appreciate subtlety. Pacific 
Rim is great, not bashing it, but I'd be praising the overall concept, the 
special effects in general, and some of the Kaiju attack patterns vs Jaeger 
ingenuity, over a scene that's physically impossible.
comments.author: Rodgerinho

comments.text:
i like ur sense of logic Rodgerinho i was thinking the same thing when i

comments.author: michael wime

comments.text:
Yeah, just watch Titanic, it's pretty well established even in mainstream 
common sense that if you exert any sort of force on a ship, it's going to 
crack and break in two. They dragged it along, swung it back, then used it 
like a baseball bat against the Kaiju. It wouldn't even have survived he 
way it was being dragged along...

This movie was terrible to me , When we go see a robot fighting gigantic 
alien monsters movie we don't want to see love bullshit' when we go to see 
Resident Evil do we go to see people kissing, no we go to see to see Alice 
fuck shit up.﻿
top_comment.author: Aaron Starrk

comments.text:
Actually, you went to see a robot fighting giant monsters movie and that's 
exactly what you saw. The movie, by common rules of film making, must have 
some semblance of story in order to be accepted and funded by the studios. 
No matter what, there has to be something there. So your argument is 
invalid.
comments.author: Kyero Nelma

comments.text:
they didn't even kiss, the romance was, at best, implied. If you thought 
this movie had kissy dovey love, I bet you think handholding counts as rape
comments.author: Flubbering Philistine

top_comment.text:
The after credits scene was the lamest ever!
The writing was lame.
Character development was non-existent.
Too many clichés.
Idris Elba was wasted in this flick.
Too much CGI.
Too American.

@ Doug Dugle: you just disqualified yourself from this comment section. Go 
home you "casual" guy and please don't try to get involved in any adult 
conversation ever again. Nothing personal, thank you.﻿
top_comment.author: Wiebke Gätjen

comments.text: Fun Fact! The character archetypes were intentional.
comments.author: The Trespasser

comments.text:
Yeah. If the plot is a bit dumb, like pacific rim, I can tolerate it. But I 
saw almost every plot twist in Gravity coming from a mile away. If it had a 
few better ideas it would have been incredible. But pr was a little dumb, 
like most other good movies.
comments.author: jacob stevenson (Glitch)

comments.text:
Okay, now I'm starting to see where your coming from. Truthfully I don't 
blame you, but you gotta understand some circumstances it's not about plot, 
it's about entertainment value. I Love an outstanding plot as much as 
anyone else, but sometimes you just have to let things be. example, Tron 
legacy, Great soundtrack, awesome fight sequences, but very shaky plot. Did 
not stop it from being a good, or at the very least, an entertaining movie. 
Pacific rim's big thing is taking a genre that very few directors are 
willing to work with, and turn into something that we haven't seen since 
independence day. Simple plot does not always mean stupid movie, numbered 
cliche's do not always mean horrible writing. I completely get where you're 
coming from, just saying once in a while to lower your expectations, sit 
down, and watch the movie.
comments.author: HeinkelG2

comments.text:
Having finally watched gravity, I can say it was horrible. THe plot, which 
is in my opinion the best part of any movie, was shit. If your plot is 
shit, then characters or cgi can't save it.
comments.author: jacob stevenson (Glitch)

comments.text:
+HK-Generation 2
Elysium was a disappointment. Director and cast had us hoping for a much 
better movie. But maybe it's just impossible to come up with another 
'District 9' after your name is established. At least they tried, while in 
Pac Rim Guillermo del Toro obviously gave up in minute one. As his quirky 
and entertaining 'Hell Boy' shows, he's quite a capable director who 
manages to bring charme and joy into b-movie source material. We expected 
that with a giant budget and all the merketing and hype he'd up his game. 
Unfortunately didn't happen.
comments.author: Wiebke Gätjen

comments.text:
+Wiebke Gätjen whoah, woah, woah. now I'm just curious. If you didn't like 
Pacific rim, and you didn't like Gravity, then what the fuck do you like? 
those two examples alone leave me wondering what your cinematic preference. 
Just out of the dark, how did you like Elysium?
comments.author: HeinkelG2

comments.text:
I do agree with no interesting twists, and most of the points. But I 
facepalm if you expected anything OTHER than giant cgi robots fighting 
giant cgi monsters. The writing, and other stuff accomplished that goal. I 
really didn't like the "American underdog: thing.If it had been any of the 
other jaegers (Cherno), it would have been a better movie.
comments.author: jacob stevenson (Glitch)

comments.text:
+jacob stevenson
Well, Jacob, you obviously fall square into H'wood's target group of 
uncritical, mostly young, not too intelligent males who don't expect much 
from a movie apart from some cool CGI. \o/ Go, Team America!!! Whoohoo! \o/

The aftercredits joke was unfunny, that it was.

Idris Elba was indeed great, that's why I think he was wasted in a crap 
movie like this.

I didn't watch Gravity because the premise is already too lame to wake my 
apetite, so I can't compare it.

If the writing was intended to accomplish facepalms by the audience then it 
did a good job indeed.

The characters came fresh from the screeenwriter's guild and were obviously 
created by using the typical formula:
broken hero: check
mild love interest: check
oldschool about to die commanding officer: check
goofy scientists: check
a bad guy who turns out not to be too bad: check
unsympathetic (and of course failing) allies: check
American underdog crew saves the day: check

All that would be okay if they were presented in a more convincing way and 
not just as throwaway dummies.

There were no interesting twists in the plot but all the more potholes in 
the story.
comments.author: Wiebke Gätjen

comments.text:
The after credits scene was an in joke.
Writing accomplished what it was intended.
Character development accomplished what it needed it
I saw less clichés than there were in gravity.
Idris Elba was great
Oh, you wanted it to be made like Godzilla? with suits?
How is it too "American" what does that even mean?
comments.author: jacob stevenson (Glitch)

top_comment.text:
was this movie a giant rip off of every giant robot anime? YES. was it 
cool? HELL YES!! and im ok with that. ﻿
top_comment.author: Bryan Mancilla

comments.text:
that's because anime monster movies are kind of their own genre, and have 
been since 1954.

comments.text:
+HK-Generation 2 i didn't
 rip-off in a bad way. i loved the movie, but its VERY similar to anime 
robot movies
comments.author: Bryan Mancilla

comments.text:
I feel like using the word "rip-off" is a little too harsh. Sure, it's not 
the very first robot monster movie to ever exist, but his has originality 
in it's execution. I've been watching Kaiju movies since I was seven, maybe 
younger, and pacific rim is the best this kind of business has to offer. 
Quoting movie bob on this "everything that's wrong with it feels kinda 
right". To put it to the point, Pacific rim is not a Rip off, it's a movie 
that follows it's genre.
comments.author: HeinkelG2

comments.author: Needsome Citations

comments.text:
First, there are a shitload of animes and Japanese movies and shows based 
off this extremely common premise besides Evangelion. It is an entire genre 
for crying out loud so it was most defiantly, unquestionably not ripped off 
Evangelion. Second, if you watched anything with Del Toro talking about 
this movie he will specifically admit that anime and the Japanese movie 
scene was his primary inspiration. It was an homage not a rip off.

illogical cgi and crap dialogue alongside lame actor-performance...

So yeah. I'll give it 1/10 for the graphical awesomeness...

top_comment.text:
Those army soldiers are the most generic you can find: Dollar Store, made 
in China. They are the typical "guy taking a knee with a Bren Light Machine 
Gun," "Guy slouching with a Thompson," "Several poses with Lee Enfields," 
and the famous "Guy laying prone with an M16A3 (or M4A1 depending on the 
adaptation)"﻿
top_comment.author: Jim Jones

comments.text:
I couldn't give 2 fks about those army guys... but I like your moves. 
Touche.
comments.author: BLTspace

comments.text: +Reptilian Capriccioso Interesting, I've never heard of such figures.
comments.author: Jim Jones

comments.text:
I bought a set of those once, it was mostly just those ones. But it had two 
that were lying down on their backs facing with a pistol towards their 
feet. Screw everything else life has to offer, THAT blew my mind. To this 
day, I have searched far and wide and have never found any others like 
that. The newsagents I got it from closed.
comments.author: Reptilian Capriccioso

comments.text: Forgot the minesweeper.
comments.author: Chris Charnley

comments.text:
Almost forgot the guy sitting with the mortar and the guy crawling with the 
M16A3!!!
comments.author: Jim Jones

captions.text:
Alright, Pacific Rim, man. I am pumped to
talk about this movie!

I can tell.
The only problem is... how do we decide who's

gonna do the pros and who's gonna do the cons.
What do you mean?

Well, we're both gonna want to do the pros,
so you know, how do we choose. Do we flip

a coin or what?
I do not mind doing the cons, alright? That

doesn't bother me.
You mother*cker. You didn't like Pacific Rim?!

No, that's not even remotely what I said.
I just saw enough wrong with it that I don't

mind taking the con side in an argument.
You mother*cker.

Whatever. I can't help it.
Okay. Whatever. I'm going first, though.

Do it. You go first.
The robot drags a f*cking cargo ship through

the streets of Hong Kong and beats up a giant
alien monster with it!!

Yeah, that was pretty awesome.
(That was easy)

Okay, my turn, now. That's only awesome at
the expense of story and character.

What?
Like, it's so obvious they spent so much on

the robots they just had an intern who watched
too many Roland Emmerich movies be the screenwriter.

What's there to script? Exterior: Day: Robot
punches monster.

That's about how they approached it, yeah.
I mean, they couldn't have more clichés in

this movie if they tried. Will the two new
partners get along? Will they fall in love?

Will the grizzled old veteran come out of
retirement to save the day? Will the scientist

storyline make me want to choke a b*tch? None
of those questions have good answers.

Man, I liked all that stuff. Are you—do
you mean to tell me that you knew they were

going to fall in love, like, in the beginning
of the movie? Cause I didn't see that coming

at all.
That's only because you were too busy masturbating

to the robot fights.
I did that when I got home, alright? I am

an adult.
Whatever. It's my point. (That was easy)

The robot drags a f*cking cargo ship through
the streets of Hong Kong and beats up a giant

alien monster with it!!
I know, but you already used that.

It's worth more than one point!
No, it's not. Not according to the rules.

(That was easy) I'm sorry. Now, let's talk
about the accents for a second.

Accents?
I'd like to talk about the accents. Specificall

Idris Elba. That guy's a god of accents. I
watched all 5 seasons of The Wire twice before

I even knew he was British. But what the hell
is up with his accent in this movie? It's

like, Scottish at times, and English at times,
and a little Australian, South African. It's

all over the place. It's really distracting.
I didn't notice. I was too busy paying attention

to the bad-ass locker-room speeches.
If you didn't notice the accents, then you

can't argue against that. (That was easy).
That one's mine too.

Alright, my turn. The bad-ass locker room
speeches!

You know, I'm kinda glad you did that, actually.
Because the speeches are, indeed, terrible.

Like, they're cheesy—there's one speech
where it's just him and the other guy talking

in a room, and he starts screaming all of
the sudden like there's a thousand guys needing

to be inspired. It's ridiculous. (That was
easy).

You have to give me a chance to argue back.
Fine, argue back.

Those speeches were inspiring to me. Dude,
what do you want from a giant robot punching

aliens movie, like, Oscar-caliber acting?
I wish you could hear how you sound right

now. You sound exactly like those people who
defend their love of the Transformers movies

by saying basically the same thing. Look,
I don't mind if the movie wants to say, "Hey,

there's a crack in the ocean and aliens can
come through it," and then never address it

again. That's fine with me. I don't care if
they want to say, you know, robot fighting

is more important to us than character development.
That's fine with me. But even the "don't take

me seriously" fun, casual movie can still
be made well. Don't you think?

The robot drags a f*cking cargo ship through
the streets of Hong Kong and beats up a giant

alien monster with it!!
Man, you are the reason they're gonna make

six more of these things over the next ten
years.

That... sounds awesome to me.
Pacific Rim 2: More Rimming

Man, I am all over that sh*t.
Pacific Rim 2: More Inception Sounds.

Okay, that was a little distracting.
BWAAAAAAAAHHHM!

BWAAAAAAAAHHHM!
How many people do you think stayed for the

after-credits scene in this movie?
Pacific Rim has an after-credits scene?

title: Pacific Rim Debate - Conversations With Myself About Movies
